basics.description: **Note:** Please refer to the following before installing the solution: • Review the solution [Release Notes](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/tree/master/Solutions/Morphisec/ReleaseNotes.md) • There may be [known issues](https://aka.ms/sentinelsolutionsknownissues) pertaining to this Solution, please refer to them before installing. The [Morphisec](https://www.morphisec.com/) solution for Microsoft Sentinel enables you to integrate vital insights from your security products with the Morphisec Data Connector for Microsoft Sentinel and expand your analytical capabilities with search and correlation, threat intelligence, and customized alerts. With a single, cross-product view, you can make real-time, data-backed decisions to protect your most important assets. **Data Connectors:** 1, **Parsers:** 1, **Analytic Rules:** 3 [Learn more about Microsoft Sentinel](https://aka.ms/azuresentinel) | [Learn more about Solutions](https://aka.ms/azuresentinelsolutionsdoc)

options.text: This Solution installs the data connector for Morphisec API Data Connector (via Codeless Connector Framework). You can get Morphisec API Data Connector (via Codeless Connector Framework) data in your Microsoft Sentinel workspace. After installing the solution, configure and enable this data connector by following guidance in Manage solution view.

link.label: Learn more about connecting data sources

options.text: This solution installs a parser that transforms the raw Morphisec logs into a normalized schema. After installing the solution, the parser will be available in your Microsoft Sentinel workspace.
Parses Morphisec logs to provide normalized fields for easier analysis and correlation with other security data sources.
This solution installs the following analytic rule templates. After installing the solution, create and enable analytic rules in Manage solution view.
Triggers an incident for every Morphisec alert whose attacks severity is critical.
Triggers an incident when a device generates 5 or more Medium or High severity alerts, indicating potential compromise.
Triggers an incident when the same process name appears in 50 or more alerts across multiple devices, suggesting widespread activity.
